Input.threadtitle: What could you do with maps that are updated every 24 hours?
Input.posts:
One of the last lines in Lecture 2 was ' The Geospatial Revolution has brought us closer, but we’re still a really long way away from having real-time Geographic information about everything at every second. ' While this is true, there's a newer company here (SF) that's trying to address that issue by creating an updated map of the earth every 24 hours! They launched their initial set of satellites (I believe around 28) just a few months ago, which if I remember right, gives them the ability to create up to date maps of the earth every month or so. But with some more funding, they are upping that number to nearly 100, which means they'll be able to provide updated mapping every 24 hours. So I'm interested to hear people's ideas on what you could do with that data! Especially around humanitarian crises, environmental disasters, storms, global warming, deforestation, etc. If you aren't familiar with Planet Labs, go check them out ( www.planet.com ) or some of their videos.
Upvotes:
1
Updated maps every 24 hours..That is big isn't it? I believe that would make my world so unstable.. Well typically,topographically there wont be much difference in 24 hours.The soil wont erode, the mountains wont build up, the rivers wont widen or shrink...but with respect to calamities, it will be a very efficient way of how your maps look at a particular point of time. But We need to have quick response for that instead of waiting for 24 hours. A system which we can pull and push to know how a flood has changed the landscape temporarily, how a tornado, a cyclone, or a tsunami has changed the landscape and how I can access a safe area..That will be a huge boost for relief workers.

I think there's one thing to clear the air about what Planet Labs is offering. When they are offering a new map every 24 hours, you have to remember that is a snapshot of the ground from a single point in time from that 24 hours. So any events that take place within a day probably won't have much value. You might grab a snapshot of an outdoor concert while it's packed, or maybe before anyone is there. It's really going to be useful over time periods that stretch over days. Per Rishi's example, evaluating the effects of natural disasters (earthquakes and the like) is a perfect example - and it might help relief organizations know where to send help. And to your point Manju, I think they will be able to see long term topographical changes - at least from the point where they start collecting data. They could watch forest deforestation, the effects of droughts, waterway changes, forest fire effects, etc. Another idea I was playing with, based on some of the discussion is tracking growth progress in areas. I'm thinking of a few scenarios Post disaster - tracking what areas are recovering and rebuilding faster than others and trying to identify the factors why Examining changes in poverty - wondering if they could track the changes to homes within slums and favellas to see if indicators for an increase in earning would appear. For example, I know on some poverty measurement systems, they look at what materials the roofs are made of. If they could track a movement to better roofing materials (from grasses to tin, for example), that may be an indicator that the income for the area is growing Made me think of another idea - might be used to evaluate population growth in slums and other informal housing areas if they can identify the number of new housing units being put together - and map that over time and you might get a growth percentage.

Input.threadtitle: What could you do with maps that are updated every 24 hours?
Input.posts:
One of the last lines in Lecture 2 was ' The Geospatial Revolution has brought us closer, but we’re still a really long way away from having real-time Geographic information about everything at every second. ' While this is true, there's a newer company here (SF) that's trying to address that issue by creating an updated map of the earth every 24 hours! They launched their initial set of satellites (I believe around 28) just a few months ago, which if I remember right, gives them the ability to create up to date maps of the earth every month or so. But with some more funding, they are upping that number to nearly 100, which means they'll be able to provide updated mapping every 24 hours. So I'm interested to hear people's ideas on what you could do with that data! Especially around humanitarian crises, environmental disasters, storms, global warming, deforestation, etc. If you aren't familiar with Planet Labs, go check them out ( www.planet.com ) or some of their videos.
